snippet.textDisplay: I have never heard it pronounced quite like that. Pontchartrain - The easiest way I can think to explain it is the phrase "Punch a Train" that will give you the flow of the word.  To get it to sound correct replace the "un" sound in punch with an "on".  So the word sounds like Ponch a train.  Don't worry New Orleans is full of words that don't sound like the should.  Take Tchoupitoulas Street for example.  it sounds like  CHOP-i-TOO-ləs.
snippet.textOriginal: I have never heard it pronounced quite like that. snippet.textDisplay: I think the bridge if built (which I seriously doubt) can quickly become a rather ironic symbol if both NI and Scotland should leave the UK and return to the EU. Then all that free trade will literally be going around England thanks to that bridge, with both NI and Scotland benefiting, and the EU does have a long standing tradition of funding infrastructure projects to help local development. But then I doubt it will get started. The UK is presently too financially stretched to be able to fund a project like this. The symbolism is in just talking about the project like it could happen.
snippet.textOriginal: I think the bridge if built (which I seriously doubt) can quickly become a rather ironic symbol if both NI and Scotland should leave the UK and return to the EU. Then all that free trade will literally be going around England thanks to that bridge, with both NI and Scotland benefiting, and the EU does have a long standing tradition of funding infrastructure projects to help local development. But then I doubt it will get started. The UK is presently too financially stretched to be able to fund a project like this. The symbolism is in just talking about the project like it could happen.

snippet.textDisplay:
BILLIONS of pounds for the bridge BILLIONS for connecting highways and raillinks, though you'd have to get off rail and onto busses / trucks to get over bridge unless you super size the bridge for trains, for BILLIONS more. Scandanavia is looking to bridge waterways using floating tunnels anchored to sea bed. Which is fraught with issues of ship collisions, unlikely but given death toll and complete loss from any collision unthinkable to consider really. Weather of course can be negated by enclosing the roadway for BILLIONS more. There is no similar bridge anywhere - nothing that length over such stormy and deep waters requiring many KILOMETERS supported by 300 meter towers from seabed to tower top, anchored another 100 meters into sea floor ea ringed by a protective barrier the size of the biggest oil rig (and those rigs cost one billion ea to build and anchor and millions a year to maintain) to fend off ships. Then there is construction time, which can only occur in calm waters, how often is it calm? yeah so decades to build paying for ships workers to sit in port all the time they can't get out to work, and yeah you could only hire them in summer but you'll pay more for seasonal workers or have to suffer lower quality workers ie who ever you can find ea yr to fill up the rosters training newbies on sea safety quality control etc.. As to tolls, every bit and MORE will go to endless maintenance and given decades it will take to build you'll be doing serious maint on first towers by the time you finish the last. Even w concrete to cover steel, the extreme flexibility would create zillions of micro fissures for moisture to get at reinforcing steel, so the concrete would need to be coated or impregnated which can trap water which when frozen destroys the concrete. Again, long 'bridges' cited are all in WARM WATERS where freezing at least isn't a concern. Up close inspections of the whole thing every few years will be a full time job for hundreds, who again due to weather will spend what, at least 1/2 their time sitting around the office, shops, depots.
Not that this is more than smoke and mirrors from another right wing liar out to stuff his billionaire backers pockets, but it was fun to debunk it.
snippet.textOriginal:

Which is fraught with issues of ship collisions, unlikely but given death toll and complete loss from any collision unthinkable to consider really.  Weather of course can be negated by enclosing the roadway for BILLIONS more.  There is no similar bridge anywhere - nothing that length over such stormy and deep waters requiring many KILOMETERS supported by 300 meter towers from seabed to tower top, anchored another 100 meters into sea floor ea ringed by a protective barrier the size of the biggest oil rig (and those rigs cost one billion ea to build and anchor and millions a year to maintain) to fend off ships.  Then there is construction time, which can only occur in calm waters, how often is it calm?  yeah so decades to build paying for ships workers to sit in port all the time they can't get out to work, and yeah you could only hire them in summer but you'll pay more for seasonal workers or have to suffer lower quality workers ie who ever you can find ea yr to fill up the rosters training newbies on sea safety quality control etc..  As to tolls, every bit and MORE will go to endless maintenance and given decades it will take to build you'll be doing serious maint on first towers by the time you finish the last.  Even w concrete to cover steel, the extreme flexibility would create zillions of micro fissures for moisture to get at reinforcing steel, so the concrete would need to be coated or impregnated which can trap water which when frozen destroys the concrete.  Again, long 'bridges' cited are all in WARM WATERS where freezing at least isn't a concern. Up close inspections of the whole thing every few years will be a full time job for hundreds, who again due to weather will spend what, at least 1/2 their time sitting around the office, shops, depots.  
Not that this is more than smoke and mirrors from another right wing liar out to stuff his billionaire backers pockets, but it was fun to debunk it.

snippet.textDisplay: It would benefit the UK a lot more economically to have a bridge between Dover and Calais (shorter distance, shallower depths, more economic advantage, shared cost with France a possibility), but that would upset Brexiteers, so no way. Instead build the world's longest sea bridge to the UK's poorest member, but it will make Brexiteers/Unionists happy :)
snippet.textOriginal: It would benefit the UK a lot more economically to have a bridge between Dover and Calais (shorter distance, shallower depths, more economic advantage, shared cost with France a possibility), but that would upset Brexiteers, so no way. Instead build the world's longest sea bridge to the UK's poorest member, but it will make Brexiteers/Unionists happy :)

snippet.textDisplay:
Would be more economic sense to link Dublin to wales and have a high speed link from Belfast to Dublin. Would mean the 2.5 million in the greater Dublin region would be 2 hours away from cities like Cardiff, Liverpool and Manchester and just 3.5 hours from London.

Then scottish cities about 3. 5 hours to 4 hours.

Add 25 mins to 30 mins for people travelling from Belfast if they've a high speed link to connect to Dublin terminal.

By connecting Belfast to Scotland its gonna be to far from the main cities of the UK in England (the larger ones) and the people living in Dublin would just fly to England as it would take 6 hours to take a train to London from Dublin if not 7.

Thus project needs to be smart and realise Dublin, Liverpool, Manchester, Birmingham and London are the cities that could generate lots of cash.

Belfast is tiny and would still be 2.5 hours from Edinburgh minimum (due to Scottish terrain) and much more from English centres and unused by the 5 million in Ireland and 2 million in Dublin. Dublin to London the busiest Air route in Europe.

Also British travellers coming in would have Dublin rail links providing links to the rest of Ireland and the holyhead link in Wales but provide quick road links to northern and central England and rail.

This is smarter and instead keeps Ireland linked to Britain

snippet.textDisplay:
You have forgotten the most important benefit of such kind of intransparent mega signature infrastructure projects with unpredictable cost...

Worldwide, they are perfect opportunities for distributing gifts for maintaining networks between investment-, asset-, risk management companies, governments and the corporate world with the aim to transfer tax payers money from the bottom to the top 3% elite...It is not signal for continued trade. It is a signal for the opening of the ALL-YOU-CAN-EAT self-service buffet...CORRUPTION....MONEY LAUNDRY...ARE THE BUZZWORDS.

If you look at the origins of the wealth of the elites, you will find the same scheme...
- Stealing natural resources
- privatization of public assets
- Infrastructure projects funded by tax money, property development
- Speculation (Stock, Hedge Fonds, trading)
- war profiteers
...always accompanies with tax evasion and minimizing rights & freedoms of the regular people.

The most interesting justification is die development of new technologies in m View. But why shall the tax payer finance R&D cost of mostly foreign companies without being a shareholder of them?
The tolls will be finally paid by the people too...

And are there more important priorities...NHS, education, pension funds, housing, and so on.

The Bridge might become a gold mine but for certain not for the people.

snippet.textDisplay: There exists several ferries that carry people to and from NI, those would likely be shut down at the cost of the towns that rely on them for business. Truth be told though, trade between NI and the UK is tiny. More likely this is about the inevitable reunification of Ireland and NI. The Republic would welcome the bridge as trade would boost their economy. NI would maybe benefit too. Would the whole Union support it though? The Scottish are annoyed at having to pay about 10% of Englands HS1. Would the English be happy paying for the Boris Bridge?

snippet.textDisplay:
I've done that crossing on the Ferry several times, and I'm sure I read somewhere that the distance from Larne to Port Patrick was no more than 15 miles.
The distance from Dover to Calais is supposed to be 21 miles, and that is clearly a longer distance than the Irish Sea crossing.

snippet.textDisplay: I can see the initial shock of making the bridge. From the risks and cost price. However, I do see much more positives then negatives. For starters, it will create jobs over those years, it will fix or upgrade roads from nearby cities to and from the bridge. It will stimulate more growth between both Ireland's and UK. And (one sided view) if UK is doing well outside of EU, then Ireland might leave EU and establish better trades. Scotland should be more optimistic about seeing how it's like to be outside of the EU and get the sample of separation before crying for independence
snippet.textOriginal: I can see the initial shock of making the bridge. From the risks and cost price. However, I do see much more positives then negatives. For starters, it will create jobs over those years, it will fix or upgrade roads from nearby cities to and from the bridge. It will stimulate more growth between both Ireland's and UK. And (one sided view) if UK is doing well outside of EU, then Ireland might leave EU and establish better trades. Scotland should be more optimistic about seeing how it's like to be outside of the EU and get the sample of separation before crying for independence

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm surprised how many people have been fooled by this "bridge". Because it has nothing to do with building a bridge.
What is happening is Johnson hates Scotland and Johnson hates our SNP and Johnson despises women with attitude such as Nicola Sturgeon.
He has no interest in a bridge because his real intent is to impose further debt on the Scottish government. Make us take the blame for it to kill off our independence movement.

That's also why he stole £4 billion off the Scottish NHS just an hour before the press release about the "bridge".

In case you haven't noticed Johnson has done everything possible to aggravate the Scots. He knows he can't stop the independence movement so he's hoping to trigger Scotland into bad behaviour and we absolutely can see through his cynical game playing and will not give him the satisfaction.

snippet.textDisplay: As much as I despise Bojo, I actually quite like the idea on paper. BUT - £20 billion? So there are thousands of people on the streets, the NHS is crumbling and many people have suffered a lot due to the government-imposed austerity. The UK has a HUNDRED times more homeless people than Japan even though there are almost twice as many people there. And Johnson wants to spend at least £20 billion on a bridge no one needs (let's be real here: it might cost as much as £60 billion)? Has Bojo found the money tree Theresa May spoke about? That's not even stupid; that's completely insane and only a complete lunatic could support this.

snippet.textDisplay: I say build it and make it pay for itself with a Toll. If Scotland gains independence it can ship goods to Ireland quicker and visa versa.

snippet.textDisplay:
KEEPER: What is the air-speed velocity of an unladen swallow?

ARTHUR: What do you mean? An African or European swallow?

KEEPER: What? I don't know that! Auuuuuuuugh!
